docs.lead_paragraph: For newborns and 97-year-olds alike, a sip of aquavit can make life calm again.

headline.main: A Pour. A Staredown. A Civilized Bonding.
headline.print_headline: A Pour. A Staredown. A Civilized Bonding.

docs.snippet: For newborns and 97-year-olds alike, a sip of aquavit can make life calm again.

docs.lead_paragraph: I WAS a colicky and fussy baby. During a visit to my grandparents' farm in Denmark, my grandmother found the antidote to my fidgeting; two or three drops of aquavit -- a vodka-like elixir beloved by Scandinavians -- into the baby bottle, and I would calm down. I've had a taste for it ever since. To this day, a bottle of Aalborg Jubilaeums Aquavit, distilled in northern Denmark, is in perpetual residence in my freezer, as it is in that of almost every Dane I know -- even in my current hometown, Los Angeles. There are many national drinks destined to provoke embarrassing ethnic dancing, folk songs and fierce hangovers. The Russians have vodka. The Greeks have ouzo. The Italians Strega. But aquavit, which the Danes have been drinking for some 500 years, is different.

headline.main: A Pour. A Staredown. A Civilized Bonding.

docs.abstract: Rituals column on aquavit, vodka-like beverage distilled from potatoes and wheat and beloved by Scandinavians; photo (M)
